awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: Worth the Effort: Measuring and Predicting Investment in a Costly Application Process
awd_abstract_narration:
Before firms can hire workers from a pool of applicants, they must attract the right candidates to apply for the job in the first place. On the worker’s side, applying for a job takes time and effort, and (in states where this is legal) sometimes even costs money. While these costs are guaranteed, the desired outcome of an application (a job offer) is usually not; so workers must weigh the real, present cost against the expected future benefit of applying. This project frames applying for a job as a type of investment, and studies how the factors that influence a person’s investment decisions -- such as their willingness to take risks, or how optimistic they are about future returns -- might also affect the decision to apply for a job. Firms might think they are attracting all the best candidates for the job when they are actually discouraging suitable candidates who think applying is too risky or not worth their time (for reasons that have nothing to do with the candidate’s talents and skills). For example, research shows that women on average are less willing to take risks than men are. This implies that, when the outcome of a job application is uncertain or the likelihood of being selected is low, women would be less likely than men to “invest” in the application process, especially if that process is very costly. This project experimentally tests whether changing the cost of applying for a job affects who decides to apply, and whether factors such as gender, willingness to take risks, and the nature of the job affect the degree to which someone gets discouraged by a high application cost. The data gathered from this project should help firms improve their hiring processes to attract the best candidates and reduce unintentional discrimination. This evidence could also be used in other contexts where applications (and application costs) are common, such as higher education.

The primary goal of this project is to study how characteristics ostensibly unrelated to on-the-job productivity affect an individual’s willingness to pay an application cost. The project is designed around an experiment in which participants will face random variation in the cost of applying to complete a task for payment. Multiple types of tasks will be offered to subjects. Some subjects will face only a minimal effort cost to apply, while others will face either a higher effort cost or a monetary cost. Any subjects who apply for a task will be asked to bet on their own likelihood of receiving an offer, in order to elicit their expectations. All subjects, regardless of application decisions, will be surveyed on their skills, their beliefs and tastes, and identity characteristics such as gender. The researchers will use the data gathered on which participants applied for which tasks to estimate a probability model of the decision to apply for a job. This model will incorporate the type of task, the nature and magnitude of the application cost, and observable individual characteristics. A separate group of participants will be asked to review applications and select individuals they see as most likely to succeed in the task(s) they applied for, and then the selected applicants will be contacted to complete the task. This second part of the project is designed to test whether changing the nature of an application cost affects the distribution of applicants or a recruiter’s ability to identify the best candidates for a job. Overall, the project aims to contribute to the job search literature by experimentally testing several explanations for why equally qualified candidates may not sort identically across job opportunities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Workers expend time, effort, and physical resources to search for and apply to jobs. Because these resources are scarce, job seekers have to choose how much time they spend searching and which jobs they apply for. In addition, individual employers can decide how “costly” it is to apply for a job with their firm. For example, compare a firm that requires all applicants to submit a cover letter, take an online assessment, or fill out a questionnaire versus a firm that allows workers to apply with the click of a button (which can be an option for pre-registered users on certain job sites such as LinkedIn). Different people can have different willingness to “pay” these up-front application costs based on characteristics that have nothing to do with how qualified they are for the job in question. For example, someone who is simply more optimistic at baseline about how likely they are to get hired should be willing to pay a higher up-front cost in order to apply for a job. On the other hand, someone who finds the entire process of applying for a job particularly unpleasant is more likely to shy away from a particularly costly application process. Employers should know how changing the cost of applying for a job affects who decides to apply, since a firm generally cannot hire a worker who doesn’t apply and make themselves known to the firm in the first place.

This award funded an online experiment in which we randomly varied the cost of applying for a job and studied how it affected the distribution of applicants. We found that changing the cost of applying had the most significant effect on the gender of applicants. In particular, women are significantly less likely than equally qualified men to apply for a job when applying only involves clicking a button, but the gender gap in willingness to apply shrinks when an application cost is introduced. Our best explanation for this result, based on data we collected from all participants in the experiment, is that women who are likely to perform poorly on the job if hired are less willing to apply than women who are likely to perform well on the job, even when applying doesn’t cost them anything. On the other hand, men don’t base their application decisions on how well they’re likely to perform on the job unless applying carries some sort of tangible cost, such as paying an application fee or having to write a cover letter.

We were also able to use award funds to run a follow-up hiring experiment, in which we studied whether requiring an application fee or a cover letter changed how recruiters made decisions about who to hire. What we found is that when recruiters read cover letters, they become significantly more likely to hire a man over an equally qualified woman. Thus, while introducing a cover letter increases women’s proportion of applicants, including highly qualified applicants, it decreases a woman’s chances of being hired. This is most likely related to gender differences in self-promotion abilities, which have also been documented in previous economics research. Because of their bias towards male applicants, recruiters who read cover letters actually miss out on hiring the most productive workers.

The results of this experiment have important implications for employers and other recruiters. Employers should know that having a “no-cost” application process skews the gender balance of applicants towards men, but that relying on cover letters to judge worker productivity can lead to gender bias towards men in hiring. Recruiters in other fields, such as college admissions (where women tend to outnumber men in admissions) should know that men (even highly qualified men) are less willing than equally qualified women to pay application fees, and thus reducing or eliminating fees can help attract male candidates.

The outcomes of this project to date are:

(1)   A draft of a scientific article, which will comprise a key part of the co-PI’s doctoral dissertation; and,

(2)   Several (completed or scheduled) conference, seminar, and workshop presentations by the co-PI on the research project.

Future outcomes of this project will include a public-use version of the data set collected during the project that can be used by other researchers, and most likely a peer-reviewed published version of the scientific article describing the findings of the experiment.
